acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 48-hour EC50 = 8.0mg/L for crustaceans (Daphnia magna) (Test for the Ecological Effect of Chemical Substances (Ministry of the Environment), 1998), the substance was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 of 316mg/kg (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and 200-316mg/kg (HSDB (2003)), the substance was classified into Category 3.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 of > 1.4mg/L in 6-hour tests (4-hour conversion LC50: 2.1mg/kg), (IUCLID (2000)), the substance was classified into Category 4. Because its toxic concentration is higher than 90% (40 ppmV) of saturated vapour pressure concentration (188.7 ppmV), we judged that the substance was mist.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Among documented rat LD50 values of 373mg/kg (PATTY (5th, 2001)), 200mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)), 240mg/kg (ca.) (HSDB (2003)), and 500mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)), the value representing the highest hazard was used as the basis to classify the substance into Category 3.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Its classification for acute toxicity is Category 2, it is rapidly degradable (BOD degradability using 2-week standard methods: 76.9% (Biodegradation and Bioconcentration of Existing Chemical Substances under the Chemical Substances Control Law, 1977)), and it is estimated to be prone to bioaccumulation (log Kow = 4.4 (> 4.0, (PHYSPROP database, 2008)). Based on this information, the substance was classified into Category 2.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Since its flash point is 105degC (Ullmanns (E) (2003)), the substance was classified into "Not classified".

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: No in vivo data are available and thus classification is not possible. Among in vitro mutagenicity tests, negative results were documented from both chromosomal aberration tests using cultured mammalian cells and gene mutation tests using microorganisms.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Since its autoignition point is 240degC (Ullmanns (E) (2003)), the substance was classified into "Not classified".

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: In oral administration tests, rats were administered at 80mg/kg, a dose that induces general toxicity such as decreased body weight gain and decreased food consumption in parental rats (both sexes). This administration resulted in severely decreased survival rates in neonates, unkempt fur and neglected brood collection during nurturing periods (Toxicity Testing Reports of Environmental Chemicals (Chemicals Investigation Promoting Council)), (accessed June 2008). From these results, the substance was classified into Category 2. Although 2 of the 12 treated female rats died after 21-22 days of gestation, the dose that induced developmental toxicity (80mg/kg) was lower than the rat oral LD50 values (200mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)) and 240mg/kg (ca.) (HSDB (2003)).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Its preexisting classification for skin corrosion is Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: In primary skin irritation tests, the substance was topically applied onto 6 rabbits for 24 hours, and during the 21-day observation, the average scores of the Primary Dermal Irritation Index after 24-72 hours indicated that the substance was corrosive (HSDB (2003)). Other tests also reported that the substance was highly corrosive (IUCLID (2000)) or causes immediate necrosis (IUCLID (2000)). Thus, the substance was classified into Category 1.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In 28-day repeated oral administration tests, rats administered at 70mg/kg showed salivation and convulsions under normal conditions, suggesting that the substance has toxicological effects on the autonomic nervous system. The no-observed effect level has been documented to be 20mg/kg for both sexes (Toxicity Testing Reports of Environmental Chemicals (Chemicals Investigation Promoting Council) (2008)). Since the 90-day conversion of the NOEL 20mg/kg is 64mg/kg, which is equivalent to Category 2 guidance values, the substance was classified into Category 2 (nervous system).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
